ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left Posterior Fossa Meningioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by CT scan showing a 4-cm mass lesion pressing against the tentorium and causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear Pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Suggested by left-sided tinnitus, unsteadiness, abnormal ABR (delayed wave V, extended I-III), and dichotic deficits despite symmetrical audiogram.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds given complaints of hearing loss and tinnitus.
To evaluate neural integrity and screen for retrocochlear pathology given asymmetrical symptoms.
To visualize intracranial structures and identify the cause of neurological symptoms and retrocochlear signs.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presented with symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss and excellent speech recognition, which contradicted subjective left-sided complaints. However, retrocochlear testing (ABR and Dichotic Digits) revealed significant left-sided abnormalities. A subsequent CT scan confirmed a large left posterior fossa meningioma causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Mild to moderate bilaterally symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss; thresholds normal in low frequencies sloping to 50-60 dB HL in high frequencies.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal. Left ear showed abnormal absolute latency for wave V, extended I-III interwave interval (2.5 msec), and abnormal ILD (0.4 msec).

tests.name: Dichotic Digits Test
tests.result_summary: Poorer performance in the left ear (83%) compared to the right ear (95%).

tests.name: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan
tests.result_summary: 4-cm mass lesion (meningioma) in the left posterior fossa pressing against the tentorium, obliterating the fourth ventricle, and causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

counseling_actions: Explain that while standard hearing tests are symmetrical, processing tests confirm the reported left-sided difficulty.
Discuss the correlation between the mass, hydrocephalus, and symptoms like unsteadiness and headaches.
Advise on the necessity of neurosurgical intervention.

red_flags_present: Subjective left-sided hearing loss with symmetrical audiogram
Headaches triggered by upward gaze or coughing (intracranial pressure signs)

escalation.rationale_short: Large posterior fossa mass causing obstructive hydrocephalus requires immediate surgical management.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor recovery and auditory status following tumor removal.

expected_outcome: The tumor was removed without complication and the patient recovered well.
After surgery, the patient's left ear tinnitus changed to a clicking type sound.
